title: LR circuit - current before_after closing switch

content.question: A circuit is constructed from two resistors <math alttext="R sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="R sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, an inductor, a battery, a switch, and connecting wires, as shown. None of the values of the circuit components are known. The switch is initially open. At time <math alttext="t sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, the switch is closed and remains in the closed position until the circuit reaches steady state at time <math alttext="t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. How does the current <math alttext="I sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> in Resistor <math alttext="R sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> at time <math alttext="t sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> compare to the current <math alttext="I sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> in Resistor <math alttext="R sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> at time <math alttext="t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>?

choices.label: <math alttext="I sub 0 is greater than I sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>
<math alttext="I sub 0 equals I sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="I sub 0 is less than I sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="I sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="I sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> cannot be compared without knowing the resistances of the resistors.

content.answer: <math alttext="I sub 0 equals I sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

topic.text: 13.5: Circuits with Resistors and Inductors (LR Circuits)

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
